comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Ritter was a chemist who invented "death-dealing war devices" such as "liquid fire"--he was arrested in Cleveland for a plot to blow up munitions plants: chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045211/1915-12-02/ed-...

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: Obviously the same Ritter who affirmed to have received USD 400 from Ernst (Ernest) Ludwig, the Austrian consul at Cleveland, for affidavits charging that the liner Lusitania carried guncotton when sunk. (The New York Times, December 3, 1915) E. Ludwig: In other sources he is named "Dr. Ritter von Rettegh", see www.cardinalhistory.com/uploads/1/2/6/4/12646906/scn_0013..., Page 50 N. 5. Another article about him in Rogue River courier., December 01, 1915, DAILY EDITION, Page 1 , column 5 "PROPOSED LIQUID FIRE AS WEAPON TO TAKE WILSON'S LIFE". In 1921, Dr. E. W. Ritter, alias Dr. Wisky Ritter von Rettegh was charged of passing bogus checks (The Washington times., September 25, 1921, SUNDAY AFTERNOON, Page 26, "DOCTOR WANTED HERE AS FORGER JUMPS HIS BOND")
